data.question: Which of the following is a true statement about the Scrum principles?
items: It's OK to follow principles when you can, what's important is to do the process the right way
As the Product Owner you don't have responsibility for every principle (e.g., only the development teams are concerned with iterative development)
As the Product Owner you have responsibility for all of the principles
The principles are independent and may conflict with organizational policy. So adopt the ones that are consistent with the enterprise
data.explanation: Scrum is based on the principles. While processes are important, they are based on the under-lying principles. It is important that all of the principles are followed all of the time. Everyone involved in the project has the same responsibility. C is the correct answer.

data.question: Which of the following is the best reason Empirical Process Control (EPC) is important to the Product Owner?
items: The Product Owner relies on visibility so that artifacts are visible to everyone with a stake in the outcomes. There is a common language and agreement to what constitutes, Done. Inspecting everything builds quality into the development process by measuring current against expectation. If inspection reveals an out of tolerance area, appropriate changes can be made -- and visibility means the product owner knows it
EPC is the basis for planning Sprints, the Daily Standup and the review/retrospect processes
EPC is no more critical to Scrum than any of the other principles
The real focus of EPC is common language and process understanding. It is the basis of how the Product Owner communicates the organizational change that is required for successful Scrum efforts
data.explanation: While there are elements of truth in all of the answers, the best reason is given in A.

data.question: You are the Product Owner on a project; what, if any, are the differences in team selection compared to traditional project management?
items: There isn't really a difference, both approaches to project management (traditional and Scrum) use cross-functional teams
Scrum requires the use of specially trained developers who understand Scrum processes

Because there is no project manager (though the Product Owner might be the closest thing to it), on a Scrum project, team selection doesn't require the same formal approvals as traditional project management
Traditional project management schedules resources and capabilities while scrum efforts focus more on building collaborating teams
data.explanation: D is correct. There is an exercise in this chapter that addresses another aspect of this question.

data.question: What is the role of the Product Owner (PO) during the Plan & Estimate phase?
items: The PO is concerned with what it will take to estimate the effort
The PO is focused on decomposing epics into estimate-able stories
The PO works with the development team to define what is required to create the deliverables for the Sprint
The primary focus for the PO is both defining tasks to estimate the effort and assigning ownership for them
data.explanation: A is correct. While the PO does help decompose epics into estimate-able stories, that isn't the primary role for the PO. The primary focus if the overall estimation effort.

data.question:
Which of the following are Product Owner responsibilities?
A. Define the project vision
B. Determine the Scrum Team members
C. Approve User Stories
items: A and B
A and C
B and C
All of the above
data.explanation: D is correct.

data.question:
Which one of the following are Product Owner responsibilities?
A. Facilitate collaboration with stakeholders
B. Most knowledgeable person about Scrum
C. Writes the acceptance criteria and the Definition of Done for every user story
D. Create the product vision
E. Participate in Sprint review and retrospect meetings
F. Confirms business justification for projects
G. Creates epics and user stories
items: B, D, F, G
A, C, E
C and E only
A, D, F, G
data.explanation: The Product Owner may participate in the Retrospect Sprint meeting, at the discretion of the team, it's not a given. The Product may write the Definition of Done, but that isn't on a per story basis. D is correct.

data.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the authorities the Product Owner has?
items: Clarifies requirements and acceptance criteria
Make decisions on behalf of the Team
Helps determines Scrum team members
Does not introduce changes after the Sprint has started
data.explanation: The team makes decisions on the part of the team; that is part of the essence of self-organization. B is correct.

data.question: Which statement is true about the role of the Product Owner (PO) and the Scrum Master (SM)?
items: The PO is responsible for all processes that deliver value; the SM is the servant leader of the effort
The SM owns the Scrum process; the PO owns the business value
The PO is the voice of the customer; the SM is the voice of the team
The SM helps create a workable backlog; the PO is responsible for the big picture
data.explanation: B is correct.

data.question: What is the role of the Product Owner (PO) in quality, change and risk?
items: The PO approves changes within tolerances, writes the acceptance criteria, and owns risks
The PO doesn't get involved with small changes, owns the risks, and quality is integrated into organizational quality controls
Because Scrum allows the plan to evolve (change) during development, it allows changes. Quality is based on a Definition of Done within a Sprint. The PO is the risk owner

The basis of quality in Sprint is the Deming (PDCA) cycle. Change is restricted to authorization by the Product Owner as the primary voice of the customer. Risk is handled based on organizational policies and procedures
data.explanation: A is correct.

data.question: How does the Product Owner interact with the Scrum Team?
items: The PO assigns user stories, participates in Sprint Reviews, and approves changes
The PO writes the acceptance criteria for user stories and works with the team to clarify any issues or concerns
The PO has minimal interaction with the team except at the beginning and end of each Sprint (Sprint planning reviews)
The PO interactions with the team are facilitated by the Scrum Master
data.explanation: B is correct.

data.question:
What is the purpose for the Project Vision statement?
A. Define the overall scope of the effort
B. Identifies the customers and users
C. Demonstrates a competitive advantage or difference
items: A and B
A and C
B and C
All of the above
data.explanation: D is correct. There is an exercise that amplifies this answer.

data.question: Which of the following is most correct about the Sprint Planning Meeting?
items: The entire core team is present for the meeting
The meeting is time-boxed to 4-hours
The meeting is actually two separate meetings
The Scrum Team uses the meeting to determine which stories they'll select from the Prioritized Product Backlog
data.explanation: While it is true that Sprint Planning Meetings are time-boxed, the time is based on the length of the Sprint. The Product Owner attends the first part of the meeting but is on-call for the second half if the team needs more information. So, while it is technically true that the Sprint Planning Meeting is divided into two sections, it's really one meeting with slightly different purposes in each half: story (and acceptance criteria) clarification and selection followed by a How-to meeting to turn the stories into a deliverables during the Sprint. D is the most correct answer.

data.question: Which statement is MOST correct about the Prioritized Product Backlog (PPB)?
items: The PPB defines the overall work on the project. It is archived when the product closes
The PPB contains user stories and bugs that need to be addressed
The PPB is maintained by the Product Owner, but anyone can make or suggests additions to it
The PPB is a dynamic list of changes, risks, bugs and epics that feed the Sprint backlogs
data.explanation: B is correct. D does not include the main component of the PPB, user stories. The PPB is never done or closed. As the owner and accountable party for the business value, only the Product Owner can make changes to the PPB.

data.question: What is the purpose for grooming the product backlog?
items: Grooming is an activity performed by the Product Owner as a part of maintaining the product backlog. It assures stories have the proper priority

The process of grooming the product backlog assigns initial story points to each item. This makes grooming a way to refine the product backlog to increase team efficiency by reducing unknowns and uncertainties to support a sustainable pace
The purpose for grooming is to remove (groom) stories that are no longer needed from the product backlog
Grooming is the first step before conducting the Sprint Planning Meeting. It selects the candidate stories for inclusion in the Sprint
data.explanation: B is the correct answer. When properly done, refining the product backlog may help to re-duce the time required for the Sprint Planning Meeting by adding clarity to the items in the product backlog. Remember the product backlog is an ordered-list (ordered by priority) of everything needed to produce the final product delivered by the project.

data.question: What is the difference between release planning in traditional project management and Scrum?
items: There is no real difference; release planning is an important aspect of every project
Release planning in tradition project management is predictive and based on a plan; release planning in Scrum is based on organizational priorities
Release planning in Scrum is not as precise as traditional project management
Release planning in Scrum is much more difficult than traditional project management because there are no project milestones in Scrum compared to traditional project management
data.explanation: The most correct answer is B. Release planning in Scrum can actually be more precise than traditional project management because it is (or should be) updated after every Sprint. In both traditional project management and Scrum, the release plan will always have ranges (or tolerances).

data.question: How does Scrum optimize quality?
items: It integrates activities to manage change and risk, provides for Empirical Process Control and measures everything against business value and criteria for Done
Quality, change and risk are all integrated with organizational standard, policies and guidelines. In this way, everything Scrum processes are never at odds with the organization
The Scrum Guidance Body working with the organization determines the appropriate way to handle quality, change and risk
Quality, change and risk are all driven by and based on the Project Vision that defines customer expectations in these areas
data.explanation: A is correct.

data.question:
The purpose for the Acceptance Criteria isâ€¦?
A. to make sure there is clarity regarding what the team must produce
B. to separate User Story from Epic
C. to make sure the team only does what was committed at the beginning of the Sprint
D. to help the team determine the complexity of the effort to assist with better estimation
items: All of the above
A, B, C
A, B, D
C and D only
data.explanation: C is correct.

data.question: What is the Definition of Done?
items: A checklist of things to do
It is related to acceptance criteria and applies to each story
A set of rules that applies to the work performed during each Sprint
Established by the team for each Sprint to document what they've completed
data.explanation: C is correct. The Definition of Done is more than just a checklist.

data.question: Which of the following statements is MOST correct about the Risk Burndown Chart?
items: It is owned by the Product Owner (because the PO is the risk owner) and used to plan and mitigate risks
It is updated by the Scrum master after every Sprint
It is a predictive tool, used by the Product Owner to forecast risk and exposure during and should trend down as the project approaches completion
It provides a visible artifact to demonstrate the differences between risks that are threats and risks that are opportunities
data.explanation: C is correct.

data.question:
Which of the following is true?
A. Changes are unapproved and not added to the product backlog until they are prioritized
B. Most changes that are within defined tolerance levels can be approved by the Product Owner
items: A is True
B is True
Both are true
Both are false
data.explanation: B is correct. Changes are not added to the product backlog until they are approved.

data.question: What is the purpose for the first part of the Sprint Planning Meeting?
items: The Product Owner (PO) confirms the Prioritized Product Backlog (PPB) and selects items for inclusion in the Sprint
The PO and the Scrum Team discuss possible items that might be included in the next Sprint
The Scrum Team selects items from the top of the PPB that are appropriate for the team and works with the PO to ensure there is clarity regarding the items selected
The PO suggests user stories and the Scream Team clarifies issues
data.explanation: C is correct.

data.question: What does the term "velocity" mean?
items: It is a relative measure of the number of story points or stories completed within a Sprint
It is used to compare teams and projects with respect to efficiency
Is only useful in short term planning because the velocity will change during a project as the team gains experience
Velocity is part of Empirical Process Control. Specifically it is an aspect of team performance and efficiency made visible through transparency
data.explanation: A is correct.

data.question:
The Daily Standup is:
A. Communication within the development team
B. The basis for a status report to management
items: A is true
B is true
Both are false
Both are true
data.explanation: A is correct.

data.question: What does it mean to groom the product backlog?
items: Weeding out stories, risks, and changes that no longer apply
Grooming is a process to re-prioritize the backlog when/as business needs dictate
Another name for grooming is maintaining
Is an activity only performed by the Product Owner
data.explanation: Both A and B are included in C (the correct answer). The PO isn't the only person involved.

data.question: What is the purpose for the Sprint review meeting? How does it differ from the retrospective meeting?
items: The review demonstrates completed stories to the Product Owner and stakeholders. Retrospective meetings review process. The Product Owner attends both meetings, leading the review and participating in the retrospect

The review demonstrates completed stories to the Product Owner and stakeholders. Retrospective meetings review process. The Product Owner participates in the review meeting and may be invited to participate in the retrospect
The retrospect demonstrates completed stories to the Product Owner and stakeholders. Review meetings review process for improvement and lessons learned
The outputs of the review include changes to product and process, the output of the retrospect meeting includes changes to the product backlog
data.explanation: B is correct.
